I was looking for an enclosure/holder for a voltmeter and temperature display, but couldn't find anything existing that was what I was looking for. I built these to screw onto the side of my printer enclosure (Stuva cabinet from IKEA).

To install, just snap the display into the enclosure and screw the enclosure onto whatever surface you'd like. I drilled a hole to run the wires through and then installed the display, so the hole is hidden.

The displays I purchased and used were:

title: Solidoodle Dual 40MM Fan Mount for Printrboard

description.text: This board was designed by Gabe Albitz and has the offset mounting hole on the bottom right that allows for clearance of the B type USB cable end. Printed in PLA 180. I was designed in AutoCAD 2011.
I scaled this up by 25.4 and came out at correct dimensions.

comments.text: Weird. Maybe there are different printrboards? I have a new solidoodle 2 and when I print this (scaled up), The 40mm fan holes all come out to perfectly fit a 40mm fan, but the holes for mounting the cover to the existing posts are too far apart in both x and y. I guess one of these days I'll take the existing cover off and scan it so I can pick off the correct hole positions.
comments.author: Claghorn

comments.text: This is the first report of a problem. Maybe you can try a different slicer or different scale. Your printer is calibrated very well? Don't know, mine fits perfectly. To date there has been 18 downloads with no problems reported.There is another board that the holes are not correct for the fan. But it is for an older application. At the time i put this board on there was no other for this application. If some of these suggestions do not help then sorry i do not have another suggestion for you. Wish i did.
comments.author: Claghorn

comments.text: Yep, my bad calibration :-). It was off just a little bit. Too small to measure with the nickel test I used to set it. I needed the values to be about 98% of what I had them set to to get the holes to come out in the right place. Sorry for the false alarm, but at least I now have a new tip about printer calibration: Use something as big as possible to measure the error so you can detect smaller errors.

print_settings.Notes:: Things like the holder for the magnetic charger are very tight tolerances (you really have to push it in hard) so maybe print these separately to test them.

description.text:
A 'finished product' version of these is now available to buy at http://www.vrmagdocks.com, but you are welcome to keep using this model.

This uses these cables:
https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01CZMLQSK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

And is an EXACT fit. If your printer doesn't print very high quality then make sure you pint out these parts first.

The run for the cable is also very tight, so check this as well. I have painted these after printing, but it might be easiest to break the model down if you want different colours, painting as one piece was a pain. It will also make it easier to print if you break it down into pieces.

The little right angle thing is a plug that should slot in to cover the gap where the wire goes in. I think it might need shrinking a touch to fit properly however, I've not tested it yet.
Good luck, let me know if you have any problems!

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Yes

Resolution:

0.09

any

Notes:

Not sure how well this will work on a lower quality print, my printer produces a very good finish with minimal layer lines, often an Acetone smooth will completely smooth the surface.

Things like the holder for the magnetic charger are very tight tolerances (you really have to push it in hard) so maybe print these separately to test them.

After downloading and using the swiss army key holder i decided i would like it to be slimmer so i got to work and created the tactical key holder. To be honest the only tactical thing about it is its black but i think it has a military look to it. There is two versions on with a key chain hole and one with out.

• print the two halfs
  • place m3 screws in the holes
  • put key through the screw on the left or the right place on the screws that remain to create an even level for the top plate to sit on
  • put other half on top of the screw add 3 nyloc m3 nuts to hold it all together
  • loosen or tighten screws to key moves out with out to much force

print_settings.Notes:: The board was printed with 30% infill to save plastic and decrease the mass of the board. With the current fill, the board weighs 15 lbs (6.8 kg).

description.text: My parents wouldn't let me buy a long board, so I printed one! The board was designed in Solidworks in two variants: a normal 4 wheel, and a 8 wheel board. The purpose of the 8 wheels was to have the flexibility to ride the long board during the winter in the snow and rain. The hinged brackets that held each pair of wheels allows the board to go over curbs, sticks, and rocks with ease. I currently use the 4 wheel design as it is summer here in Minnesota. All the parts were printed on a home built Rostock Delta printer in both ABS and PLA. Printing Time Estimate: 120-140 hrs.

Printer:

DIY Rostock Delta

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30% Full Honeycomb

Notes:

The board was printed with 30% infill to save plastic and decrease the mass of the board. With the current fill, the board weighs 15 lbs (6.8 kg).

Bro, Do you even loft? - Solidworks joke ;)

As a mechanical engineering student, I am fluent with Solidworks. This was not for a class or anything, just a fun project. I made rough sketches in my notebook during Calculus and translated that to a sketch on the computer. Designing all the parts took 2 days and another 5 hours to assemble both models. I am currently working on design for an all electric long board.

Center Steel Rods

I used 5/16" steel drill rods for the internal support on the board. 8mm steel drill rods would work as well. Each rod was 36" long and was threaded 1-2 inches on either end on a manual lathe. I used Nylon thread-locking nuts. There are 6 rods all together.

comments.text: Its a really stiff ride. I had never long boarded before building this so I had no idea that normal boards flexed. Besides the fact that it doesn't flex, it rides great. I have been working on an electric printed board for a while now. Hopefully it will be finished in the next week. The board I am holding in my profile pic is one piece and made out of Nylon. I have access to some really large Stratasys printers at work so thats how I was able to make it in one piece. The final design is actually running right now over the weekend on a Fortus 900 out of Ultem 1010. I can't wait to see how it turns out!

Umberto Boccioni (Italian pronunciation: [umˈbɛrto botˈtʃoːni]; 19 October 1882 – 17 August 1916) was an influential Italian painter and sculptor. He helped shape the revolutionary aesthetic of the Futurism movement as one of its principal figures. Despite his short life, his approach to the dynamism of form and the deconstruction of solid mass guided artists long after his death. His works are held by many public art museums, and in 1988 the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York organized a major retrospective of 100 pieces.
(Wiki)

description.text:
These files are based on acrylic components sent to me by Jersey Jack Pinball. I remodeled them for 3D printing and am sharing them here with the expressed permission of Jack Guarnieri.

The parts are installed in front of the monster faces to stop pinballs from falling into the hole when the monsters are raised. They should be printed with transparent filament in order for the strobe light to remain effective.

The three left creatures use the standard part whereas the Warg has a special part with a notch for his nose. Installation requires removal of the monster mechs. Use #8 1/2" wood screws to attach them.

Size of the tangram can be changed in the openscad file.

title: 2 Liter Bottle Holder with Funnel and Cap

description.text:
I needed to screw a 2 Liter bottle into something I am building in OpenSCAD, and couldn't find anything, so I made this. And since it seems useful, I'm sharing it.
Files are:
  • bottleNeck.stl is a part to print that holds a bottle. Add this to your design where you want to screw in a bottle.
  • bottleNegative.stl can be subtracted from your design to make a hole into which you can screw a bottle
  • 2LBottleFunnel is a funnel that screws onto a 2 Liter Bottle.
  • 2LBottleCap is a cap that screws onto a 3 Liter Bottle.
  • 2LBottleHolder.scad is the source code, which you can incorporate into your designs. It's commented.
    Thanks for eagleapex for making and then deleting his 2 Liter bottle threads, and linking ti the specs at http://www.threadspecs.com/assets/Threadspecs/ISBT-PCO-1881-Finish-3784253-18.pdf, It inspired me to make this.

comments.text: Thank you for sharing your design. It's much more helpful for own projects than the most others only sharing the stl-files.

This is My Little Joker.

I didn't like any of the Joker found here on thingiverse. Either they were Heath Ledger, or versions of the Joker that I didn't like, or there was something horribly wrong with the mesh that even IF you could fix it after hours and hours of work, the result would be dissatisfying. So I made my own. My goal was to create a Joker that did not only combine various versions of him, but would also be recognizable as the Joker without paint. I think I achieved that, as I sent an unpainted screenshot to my friend and he immediately said: "THE JOKER!"

The painting I've done isn't very great, it was just a quick paint job. Also, the screenshots do not 100% match with the actual model, as when I'm finished, I see something that doesn't satisfy me, and I change it. So the actual model is better than the screenshots. In my humble opinion that is.

For the posed versions of this model:
Sitting on the Shelf: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1576030
Want Me to Die?: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1576028
Just Humble Little Me: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1575796
I designed this in Mudbox, and painted it there as well (thank Disney for PTEX painting directly onto the model...)

Alien Life Chess Set

This is an "Alien Life" chess set. Inspired by the Black Marker in Dead Space (and 3d prints of it, found on Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1538807) this is an original chess set, designed by myself and modeled in blender. I haven't had too much experience in printing 3d models (except for another chess set I made a long while back), so any feedback or comments would be much appreciated!

Thank you so much @tselling for the most excellent pictures of the pieces lined up!

And thanks to Access3Dservices for the awesome pictures of the pieces on the print bed (black and white - full set)! Checkout their Instagram for more awesome stuff!

Thanks guys for the awesome feedback! If you have some pictures of the set I'd love to see it!

Update Log

UPDATE: MAY 22nd 2016: I have re-uploaded all the files in proper mm units (with the king being 37.25 x 37.25 x 80.75 mm or 1.46 x 1.46 x 3.18 in). I have also included a full set including 8 Pawns, 2 Rooks, 2 Bishops, 2 Knights, a King, and of course a Queen.

UPDATE: JUNE 16th 2016: I have re-uploaded (again) all the files. Thanks to the help of cymon, whose helped me make the set more print ready! Also, have run it through Microsoft / Netfabb's 3d model fixer - https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/, but if there are any issues please mention it. Again THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS... so I will occasionally make changes. These changes make the set more print friendly (especially for FFF printers), or for aesthetic reasons. While the Pawn and Rook are mostly unchanged, the bishop should be slightly more FFF friendly, the Knight looks more like a classic Knight piece, King has thicker limbs as does the Queen for easier printing.
UPDATE: JUNE 20th 2016: Uploaded new versions of King and Knight (and updated FullSet and PieceSet for those respective changes). I can say that I'm now really pleased how all the pieces came out- sorry for making so many changes. This will be my last change for a while (unless there is a glaring issue that needs resolving). Any feedback is welcomed, design or otherwise. Thanks!
UPDATE: AUGUST 19th 2016, the knights aren't flat on the ground with the rest of the pieces!! Oh no! It is fixed now tho. Thanks for pointing it out 1sPiRe

Now that we have settled into the new school year (and its getting close to interims :-), its time to start making a good impression with the teachers. What better way to show our love than to print out a delicious* apple!
If you like this project or would like to learn how to start making cool things with 3D printers, check out my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media!
Don't forget to follow me on Twitter!

I printed mine using a Replicator 2X for dual color, although any printer will do. The apple and the leaf are referenced to each other, so don't have Makerware automatically position them. Rather import both, then move as a group. Print laying down.
*Although this apple may look lifelike, it is not edible.

title: Atom construction kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My son needed to make a carbon atom for his Honor Science class.  He decided that he wanted to make to coolest project this teacher had ever seen...  
So we sat and chatted a bit, and came up with this project.  
A 3-D printed 3-D carbon atom with rotating LED electrons.  
This project serves as a great introduction to some nice making skills: 3-D Modelling and Printing, Soldering, Microprocessor programming, and creating an assembly vs. single parts.

Print rings, base, and arms. in black ABS/PLA  
Slice the nucleus with the MULTIPLY option on to make as many neutrons/protons as you need, times 2, as each is a half a sphere, make the protons/neutrons a different color.  
Once we are done, I'll post pics and the arduino sketch and wiring diagram.

Made a few changes and fixes to the light house models by josemivaz and johnesc (thanks guys!).

I modified the light part to hold a 3 LED tap light. With this light (cost about $1.50, takes 3 AAA batteries) you get an impressive amount of light even in a fully lit room.

I made the clear windows thinner and modified the top to fit the thinner window piece.

When I printed the balcony piece made to fit a piece of filament I found a gap between the center tube and the base, so I eliminated the gap and the modified piece is here. My printer uses 3mm filament which wouldn't fit, so I made the rail with some left over elastic string from an earlier project.

Printing the whole lighthouse at 100% took about 50 hours in total, but it's an impressive model.

This was practice for an end of the year student project to make smaller models of some real lighthouses ... coming soon.

remixed_from.author: laird
remixed_from.title: 2 Liter Bottle Holder with Funnel and Cap

description.text:
The "FilaBottle" is a system for using 2 Liter bottles with the FilaStruder. This allows you to print large quantities of filament without having to constantly refill the hopper. And it allows you to store pre-mixed large batches of pellets in 2 Liter bottles, giving more consistency and protecting the material from humidity. Some smaller water bottles will also work, such as the blue bottle in the 'angled' photo, if they use the 2L bottle standard cap. Updated to:
  • Add a "comb" to block the flow of pellets before lifting off the Filabottle, making it easier to remove cleanly.
  • Add an "angle" version that has a 45 degree angle, which feeds pellets into the Filastruder if it's vertical.
  • Added copies of the STLs rotated for easy printing. For example, the funnel is inverted so the wide end is on the build platform.
    • To print:
  • Print either the FilaBottleV2-straight or FilaBottleV2-angle-print, depending on whether you want the bottle straight or angled
  • Print FilaBottleV2-funnel-print
  • Print FilaBottleV2-comb-print
  • If you need a cap, print FilaBottleV2-cap-print
    • Note that the funnel, comb and angle parts have two STLs. The files named -print are oriented for printing, and the other copies are oriented as they are used. To use it:
    1) Find a clean, dry 2 Liter bottle, with a cap.
    2) Screw the FilaFunnel onto the bottle. Pour in the base material and colorant.
    3) Remove the funnel, put on the cap, and shake until the colorant is evenly mixed.
    4) Remove the funnel.
    5) Screw on the FilAdapter and insert the comb. Invert the bottle and slot it into the Filastruder. If your Filastruder is horizontal, use the "straight" version, and if your Filastruder is angled or vertical, use the "angle" version.
    4) Remove the comb so the pellets flow into the Filastruder, and extrude filament.
    5) When you're done extruding for the day, replace the comb to stop the pellets, remove the bottle, and put the cap back on the bottle, to keep the plastic sealed. You might need to lift the Filadapter slightly to let the pellets loosen so you can get the comb in.

comments.author: dewclaws

comments.text: How do you grind your plastic up to make the filament?
comments.author: Zerofever

comments.text: I've been buying raw plastic pellets. They're much cheaper than buying filament. For example, OS Printing LLC (http://store.osprintingllc.comhttp://store.osprintingllc.com) sells 10 pounds of ABS for $35. It turns out that while recycling plastic is an appealing idea, it's tricky to do. First, you have to grind it into tiny pieces so that they can feed and melt, which nobody's figured out how to do for hobbyists - industrial plastic processing machines are typical industrial prices. Second, you can only use 10-20% recycled plastic in the mix, or quality suffers - that's why 100% recycled plastic is usually used to make non-consumer goods such as insulation and planks and such for construction. And because raw plastic pellets are a very common industrial material, they're really cheap. The only challenge with buying pellets is that manufacturers want to sell plastic by the ton (literally) so you need to buy through a reseller such as OS Printing or IND Hobbies (http://www.indhobbies.comhttp://www.indhobbies.com ) that buy in bulk and repackage for hobbyists.
comments.author: Zerofever

description.text: I made this for my RV because the rocker switch that extends / retracts the rear slide-out is precariously near the hall-way light switch. In the dark, these switches feel nearly identical and pressing the slide-out while someone is asleep in it, could result in adverse conditions, to say the least. The housing is designed to cover the switch (I used to automotive double-sided tape) and hinge upward to access the switch. I used some small bits of metal to complete the hinge assembly.

title: T2 belt tensioner . X axis belt tensioner

description.text:
i had been struggling to tension the x axis belt as the attachment points on my x carriage are quite close together in turn not allowing much space to get a grip on the belt to tension it properly so i came up with this printable solution.
When inserted, the Allen key acts a rotation shaft and once the clamp is tightened down, the toothed bobbin stays in place. Best printed at slow speeds If you like this then please hit the like button
Enjoy

author: Phil_Maddox

title: My Little Joker Posed: Just Humble Little Me

description.text:
I hate how all the models always just stand there. So mine doesn't. And in the case of the Joker, it makes a sarcastic bow. To the Bat, perhaps. "Oh Bats! It is only humble little me!"

I didn't like any of the Jokers found here on thingiverse. Either they were Heath Ledger, or versions of the Joker that I didn't like, or there was something horribly wrong with the mesh that even IF you could fix it after hours and hours of work, the result would be dissatisfying. So I made my own. My goal was to create a Joker that did not only combine various versions of him, but would also be recognizable as the Joker without paint. I think I achieved that, as I sent an unpainted screenshot to my friend and he immediately said: "THE JOKER!"

The painting I've done isn't very great, it was just a quick paint job. Also, the screenshots do not 100% match with the actual model, as when I'm finished, I see something that doesn't satisfy me, and I change it. So the actual model is better than the screenshots. In my humble opinion that is.

For the posed versions of this model:
Sitting on the Shelf: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1576030
Want Me to Die?: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1576028
Unposed: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1575424
I made the model in Mudbox, then I posed it in Maya.

title: Replacement part for Planet Waves guitar capo

description.text:
This is a replacement part (circled in the picture) for the Planet Waves guitar capo. The original part tends to crack and split along the grooved section, and cannot be purchased separately - rendering this very nice capo unusable.

remixed_from.author: Archrival
remixed_from.title: AR picatinny foregrip w/ tactical light

description.text:
This is a vertical pistol grip and horizontal fore grip all in one designed to fit a standard M4 length lower rail. The current file works fine however my printer cannot handle the entire piece at once. I am currently working on breaking it into 3 parts so that you can hook them together with a couple screws and print much easier. I cut the hex holes for the screws to fit a 6/32 machine screw I picked up from the local hardware store. If you want a different screw size, feel free to message me.

The "Sample Test Piece" will let you print a small piece to make sure it fits your rail before printing the entire grip. As the sample picture shows, it is designed to fit a standard set of picatinny rails.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ia8SydHX2tq

comments.text: I've been having trouble with sizing the foregrip for a rifle. I've spent days trying to figure this out can you help me?

comments.author: mrhers2

comments.text: I uploaded the new file.  I didn't have time to print the entire piece so I chopped off the handle and the front half of the hand grip but as the new picture shows, the back half slides onto my rail no problem. (lowest setting on my printer took 5 hours for that part, please forgive the color peach is the only bulk color I have left!)  If the back half fits over the rail then the front half will fit so everything should be good now.

title: GM 13 250 620 - Opel Cooling System Tube Holder

description.text:
This is a copy of original GM part 13 250 620 used for coolant tube fixing on Opel Corsa D with 1.0, 1.2, 1.4 liter Twinport engines. There is two versions of design - half-cut, which is easier to print, and one-piece option which will require some supports while printing.
I've made two halves and then just glued them together.

Original part is made of PA-66, so it may be more temperature resistant than ABS, I've used. Remember that working conditions of this part include high temperature (below 100 C I think).

!USE A 10x (1000%) SCALE FOR EXACT SIZE!

RepRap

No

Printed with 0.5 nozzle and 0.2 layer height. Heated bed with capton tape - 100 C, nozzle - 245 to make layer connection better.

The vertical clearance is kept to a minimum so taller objects can be printed. Not shown in the pictures, but a 40 mm fan is to be mounted in front of the extruder motor. Sample video: http://youtu.be/Kf_FaiNjeag

A puukko is a Finnish fixed-blade knife that's small, full of utility, and intended to be carried at all times - with the handle traditionally being made by the owner of the knife. As someone who spends close to 100% of my time making, cooking, or exploring, it's rare for more than a few hours to pass without needing a knife for the task at hand - making it easy for me to appreciate the design legacy that the puukko embodies. At the same time, however, I now live in a major city... and even if it is perfectly legal to have a small knife on your person, most people still think it's a weird thing to do. Inspired by one of my favorite design and designers - Tapio Wirkkala - I have begun iterating on a modern, high-performance, urban-appropriate knife for everyday use. The latest incarnation is presented here. It incorporates the unbelievably well made Lauri PT 77 blade (an awesome, carbon steel, progression-tempered blade with full scandi grind for incredible sharpness, edge holding, and overall strength) and an asymmetrical handle intended to allow carrying close to the body while providing a great feel in the hand. The form lends itself well to appearing utilitarian, friendly, elegant, or powerful, depending on the color and material it is printed in. This version is for left-handed use and worn on the left side of the body. Mirror the design for right-handed use. I currently use a simple leather sheath, folded and stitched, but am working on an improved design. Will post here when it's finished. Update I've been using this every day, all over the world, since the day this was first posted, and am even happier with the design now than when I started. I printed 10 more handles for gifts, in an assortment of wild color combinations. I think the results are pretty great!

Printing Details
Print at 5-10ÃÂÃÂ° off of horizontal to maximize strength. (The build direction I chose is clear from my photos.) Use external support, but not internal support. 0.1mm layers looks amazing, though thicker is possible, as the build lines add a pleasing texture to the design. I use 2.4mm walls with no infill and the strength is great. There are two versions of the file, with slightly different blade-fit tolerances: Assembly Details
The Epoxy Fit version should slip-fit the blade fairly easily, allowing it to be easily glued in to place. This seems to be ideal with carbon steel blades, as it prevents water getting into the handle and causing corrosion. The Heat Fit version is much tighter - and requires leaving the blade and the handle in the oven at 220-240ÃÂÃÂ° FAHRENHEIT for 5-10 minutes, until the handle softens slightly and you can force the blade into the handle. Once everything cools, this should also be a permanent fit. Regardless of how you attach the blade, it is necessary to cut some tang off prior to inserting it. An abrasive disc and a dremel work very well. The carbon steel is too hard to be cut by any other means. The stainless could maybe be hacksawed.

title: Housing for LCD + Keypad from RepRapWorld

description.text:
From RepRapWorld I bought their LCD + keypad, but they had no housing available.
So I developed in SolidWorks this Housing making special knobs as part of the housing.
I mounted the keypad on screws and positioned it carefull between nuts so the switches are exactly touching the buttons. Now you can push the buttons on the outside for 0,5 mm which is sufficient to operate the switches.
I made the gcode with Simplify3D. It took me almost 6 hours to print it.

author: lyamkatz

title: Customizable Monogram Pendant with multiple loops_Dual

description.text:
I added dual extruder support to this cool monogram openSCAD program by thingiverse.

The monogram is GDD. Maybe I shouldn't wear my initials so I don't get confused with any deity.

Some astute viewers may wonder how did I print 3 colors? Orange, White, and WhiteOrange.
It's a trick with dual extruders. You carefully align your nozzles so they aren't exactly level. You carefully set the flow rates of each filament so they don't flow exactly the same. You set the Cura overlap to 15% and there you are!!!

Some other astute viewers may wonder why all of my prints are this way... Errr, uhhh. Because it is tough to get the opposite on ANY of those prior conditions and keep it for longer than 1 print.

Set dual_color "On" and print_dual_top = "Combined" to preview

then
Set dual_color "On" and print_dual_top = "TopOnly" and make that an STL
Set dual_color "On" and print_dual_top = "BottomOnly" and make that an STL
Load both STLs in cura and select "dual merge."

V2

The outer ring was sometimes printed in the "top" color extruder instead
of the bottom. See the A heart B pendant picture for an example of the
bug. See the GDD picture for the fix.

V3 - Not Yet Released

When backing is specified, does it mean print the monogram on both sides? Or print a blank back?

For mono color I assume print a blank. But for dual shouldn't it be the monogram?
When I figure that question out, I write the code.

P.S. I have butchered the originator's program by adding conditionals all OVER the place.
So, if you're not printing dual you'll be less likely to find a bug if you use his original...

author: gddeen

description.text:
A customizable thumb spanner/wrench design that fits on a keyring. I've got a few examples of this file - details below.

22/05/2016 - Customizable Version Added
Unfortunately I can't get the text rendering to play nicely with the customizer so I've removed it from this version. It is still in the file with some instructions on getting it working -- the modules and variables are commented out though so if you want something with labels you probably want to download the .SCAD file and go from there.

22/05/2016
Uploaded an 8mm version (M5).

19/05/2016
Added a double sided propeller spanner for keeping handy on a key-ring so that it doesn't go missing when needed. It is designed to fit M5 and M6 nuts. The M6 fits the Emax 2204 2300kv motors.

M5 = 8mm.
M6 = 10mm.

(Flat to flat on the outside of the nut/bolt.)

A quick guide to building a spanner/wrench that works for you.
  1. Set the 'testing' variable to '1' ~ it should be there already, but still. A big tube should now show through the centre of the spanner.
  2. Measure the flat-to-flat length of the nut that you are wanting to use the spanner with and enter this into the 'test_diameter' variable. It's a good idea at this point to add in extra length for any material shrinkage you normally get from your printer. 3 to 5 mm would probably be a start.
  3. Adjust the size of the 'upper_dia' variable until the tube just fits into the inside of the spanner without intersecting the edges.
    3b. Repeat steps 2 & 3 for the 'lower_dia' variable if you want a second size on the spanner. Just make sure that the 'lower_dia' variable is smaller than the 'upper_dia'. Bad things will happen if you don't, well, might..
  4. Adjust the rest of the variables to your preferences. Make sure that the top and bottom of the render are flat. If they're not, try reducing the 'handle_thickness_2' variable slightly.
  5. Finally set the 'testing' variable to '0' to get rid of the reference tube. Then output the file and print.
This is a trophy for recognized experts that have 3D modeling skills for Autodesk inventor.

description.text:
"War Pigs aren't your everyday, 'average Joes' from Pig-Earth. These baddies will blast you apart with scrapped weapons just as quickly as they can mow down a four-course meal."

(This character was sculpted for an upcoming "Pocket Tactics" set, but it can be used for Wayfarer Tactics and RPG system- or anything else! Like everything else in the Character Compendium, this post contains both the split and whole version of this model. Enjoy, everyone!)

This character was designed for Ill Gotten Games' sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for their modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%.

If you've got some bones to spare, check out Ill Gotten Game's Patreon Page and show them some love!
